summary: reactive oxygen species (ROS) and reactive nitrogen species (RNS) can be produced continuously as a natural byproduct of the cellular metabolism when oxygen and nitrogen interact with certain molecules. these molecules play important roles in cellular signaling and homeostasis, which protect the human body against bacteria and viruses. antioxidants are used to neutralize and eliminate harmful activities of ROS and RNS through different ways to protect the human body. anti-inflammatory (Boots et al., 2008b; Rogerio et al., 2007), anti-viral (Lee et al., 2005; 2010), anti-viral (Chen et al., 2006; Davis et al., 2008) and anti-cancer (Hirpara et al., 2009; Puoci et al., 2012) properties. quercetin 3-O--(2′′-galloyl)-rhamnopyranoside (QGR) and quercetin 3-O--(2′′-galloyl)-glucopyranoside (QGG) were isolated from the aerial parts of Polygonum salicifolium and Persicaria lapathifolia (Polygonaceae) as previously. antibodies specific for phospho-IB, phospho-NF-B p65, phospho-JNK, JNK, phospho-ERK, ERK, iNOS and GAPDH were purchased from Cell Signaling Technology (USA) all other chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (USA), respectively. the mixtures were seeded in a white 96-well plate at a density of 3 105 cells per well. after incubation for 30 min, the cells were pretreated with various concentrations of each compound for 5 min in the presence of lucigenin (25 M) the cells were then stimulated with either unopsonized zymosan (0.3 mg/ml) or PMA (0.1 g/ml) peroxynitrite production cells were seeded in a 24-well plate at a density of 2.5 105 cells per well. after overnight, cells were treated with various concentrations of each compound in the presence or absence of zymosan for 24 h. triton X-100, 0.5% Nonidet P-40, 10% glycerol, 0.1% SDS, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM EGTA, 1 mM Na3VO4, 1 mM phenylmethylsulphonyl fluoride and phosphatase inhibitor cocktails. whole-cell extracts were separated on SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and transferred onto polyviny the protein-DNA complexes were separated on a 6% native polyacrylamide gel. dried gels were exposed to X-ray films at 80°C. the cells harboring pNF-B-SEAP-NPT reporter construct were pretreated for 1 h. AMP (500 nM) or phosphatidylserine (100 g/ml) were incubated with either PKA-specific peptide substrate L-R-R-A-S-L-G or PKC-specific peptide substrate P-L-S-R-T-L-S-V-A-A-K. the reaction mixtures were separated on agarose gel and then visualized under UV irradiation followed by heating at 95° antibodies specific for phospho-IB, phospho-NF-B p65, phospho-JNK, JNK, phospho-ERK, ERK, iNOS and GAPDH were purchased from Cell Signaling Technology (USA) all other chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (USA), respectively. the mixtures were seeded in a white 96-well plate at a density of 3 105 cells per well. after incubation for 30 min, the cells were pretreated with various concentrations of each compound for 5 min in the presence of lucigenin (25 M) and stimulated with either unopsonized zymosan (0.3 mg/ml) or PMA (0.1 g/ml) tric oxide in the cultured supernatants were reacted with Griess reagents. the reaction was stopped by addition with H2SO4 and the absorbance was measured with a microplate reader. glycerol, 0.1% SDS, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM EGTA, 1 mM Na3VO4, 1 mM phenylmethylsulphonyl fluoride and phosphatase inhibitor cocktails were removed by centrifugation at 13,000 rpm for 10 min. whole-cell extracts were separated on SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and transferred onto polyvinylid the protein-DNA complexes were separated on a 6% native polyacrylamide gel. dried gels were exposed to X-ray films at 80°C. the cultured supernatants were heated at 65°C for 5 min. the reaction mixtures were separated on agarose gel and visualized under UV irradiation followed by heating at 95°C for 10 min. the cell viability was measured by EZ-CyTox Enhanced Cell Viability Assay Kit (Daeil Lab Service, Korea) QGR and QGG scavenged nearly 90% of the DPPH radical at a concentration of 30 M. that was slightly greater than quercetin and the DPPH radical scavenger BHA. quercitrin, isoquercitrin and gallic acid exhibited weaker antioxidant activity than QGR and QGG. QGR, QGG and quercetin inhibited superoxide production almost completely at a concentration of 30 M. treatment with quercitrin, isoquercitrin or gallic acid resulted in 50% inhibition. PTIO was used as a positive control. QGR, QGG or quercetin treatment inhibited superoxide production almost completely at a concentration of 30 M. quercitrin, isoquercitrin and gallic acid exhibited weak inhibitory activities in PMA-stimulated RAW264.7 cells. PTIO showed greater superoxide-scavenging activity than QGR and QGG. venging activity measured as absorbance at 567 nm followed by incubation at 25°C for 5 min. results were represented as inhibition % at 100 M (A) and concentration-dependent manner (B). PDTC was used as a positive control. p 0.001 and *p 0.05 versus either the zymosan-stimulated or vehicle group. hypohalides are produced by MPO from H2O2 and either a chloride anion (Cl) or non-chlorine halide, during the respiratory burst in neutrophils. quercetin, quercitrin, isoquercitrin and gallic acid exhibited weak-to-no MPO inhibitory activity. QGR, QGG and quercetin inhibited NF-B-SEAP expression in a concentration-dependent manner, to as low as basal levels at high concentrations (100 M) but quercitrin, isoquercitrin and gallic acid had no effect on NF-B-SEAP expression compared with zymosan-stimulated cells. NF-B complex, p65/p50 and p50/p50, are indicated by an arrow. zymosan-stimulated RAW264.7 cells were pretreated with compounds for 1 h. phosphorylation and degradation of the inhibitory protein IB was assessed. QGR, QGG and quercetin inhibited DNA binding of the NF-B complex. quercitrin, isoquercitrin and gallic acid did not. iNOS expression was barely detectable in resting cells. quercetin, QGR and QGG had no effects on SEAP expression of the SRE and NFAT. the transcriptional activation of CRE is implicated in either the cAMP/PKA or JNK pathway. quercetin inhibited PKA, but not PKC activity. RAW264.7 cells were pretreated with compounds for 1 h and stimulated with zymosan for 30 min. whole-cell lysates were prepared and Western blot analysis was performed with anti-phospho-JNK, JNK and GAPDH antibodies. quercetin, isoquercitrin and gallic acid exhibited weaker antioxidant activity than QGR and QGG. the DPPH radical scavenging activity of all compounds increased in a concentration-dependent manner. quercetin (A), quercitrin and QGR (B), isoquercitrin and QGG (C), and gallic acid (D) contain quercetin and gallic acid as well as either rhamnose or glucose as a glycoside in their structures. quercitrin, isoquercitrin and gallic acid showed weaker inhibitory activities than QGR, QGG and quercetin in zymosan-stimulated RAW264.7 cells. quercetin, isoquercitrin and gallic acid showed weaker inhibitory activities than QGR, QGG and quercetin. gallic acid exhibited weak inhibitory activities in PMA-stimulated RAW264.7 cells. superoxide radicals were generated in the presence of PMS and NADH by reaction with oxygen in the air and formed formazan by reduction of NBT. quercetin and isoquercitrin exhibited an inhibitory effect against NO production at high concentrations. PDTC effectively inhibited zymosan-induced nitrite production in a concentration-dependent manner. QGR, QGG and quercetin exhibited strong inhibitory activity on ONOO production at 30 M. that was similar to PDTC, the positive control. quercitrin and isoquercitrin exhibited 50% inhibition of ONOO production. myeloperoxidase activity was measured as absorbance at 485 nm. results were represented as inhibition % at 100 M (A) and concentration-dependent manner (B) RAW264.7 cells harboring pNF-B-SEAP-NPT reporter construct were pretreated with compounds for 1 h and stimulated with zymosan for 1 h. they were then incubated for 24 h in the presence or absence of zymosan. quercetin effectively inhibited the phosphorylation and degradation of IB. the effect of quercetin and its structurally related compounds on the DNA binding activity of the NF-B complex was assessed. GG and quercetin inhibited iNOS expression, indicating that the inhibition of NO production was due to a reduction in iNOS expression. the molecular target of quercetin and QGR in NF-B signaling is differing slightly. QGR, QGG and quercetin inhibited JNK phosphorylation. but quercitrin, isoquercitrin and gallic acid did not. results indicate that quercetin and the quercetin-containing flavonoids QGR and QGG inhibited the cAMP/PKA and JNK pathways. quercetin and QGG reported activities of phosphorylation and protein levels of p47phox in human neutrophils spontaneously hypertensive rats. phosphorylation was inhibited by quercetin, QGR and QGG, but not quercitrin, isoquercitrin and gallic acid. quercetin has been used commercially to enhance blood vessel health. QGR and QGG contain quercitrin or isoquercitrin as well as galloyl moieties as their building blocks. low levels of ROS and RNS generated by natural by-products are considered beneficial for the cellular immune response against invading microorganisms. excessive amounts of these molecules generated during oxidative stress have been implicated in various pathogenic conditions. scavenging of ROS and RNS generated is important for prevention of oxidative stress-related disorders. quercetin exerts anti-inflammatory activity by inhibiting NF-B signaling. quercetin targets IKK phosphorylation, which is an upstream signal of NF-B, thereby inhibiting phosphorylation and degradation of IB and NF-B activation. quercitrin, isoquercitrin and gallic acid did not inhibit NO production and iNOS expression. iNOS expression and NO production are regulated by various transcription factors. CREB is activated by cAMP/PKA signaling. NADPH oxidase and iNOS produce superoxide, NO and ONOO. zymosan activates PKC via a receptor-mediated signaling pathway. zymosan activates PKC via a receptor-mediated signaling pathway. strong anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory activities of qurecetin, QGR and QGG than quercitrin, isoquercitrin and gallic acid resulted in regulation of the NADPH oxidase complex, specifically p47phox. our results indicated that strong anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory activities of qurecetin, QGR and QGG exhibited antioxidant activities that were significantly stronger than that of quercetin.
